thread.title: Durham-made Hitachi train in the spotlight as Queen recreates first royal rail journey

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Durham-made Hitachi train in the spotlight as Queen recreates first royal rail journey
text:
Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
North East engineering has played a starring role as the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh recreated the first train journey made by a monarch 175 years ago. 
The royal couple boarded a special service at Slough station and made the 19-minute trip to London Paddington to mark the anniversary of the journey made by Queen Victoria at midday on June 13 1842. 
While Queen Victoria’s made the journey by steam when rail travel was still in its infancy, the current monarch travelled in one of Great Western Railway’s (GWR) latest trains - an intercity express being built by Hitachi Rail at its factory in Newton Aycliffe , County Durham . The factory is building 57 new trains for the Great Western Railway, one of a number of orders in the UK that is supporting the £82m facility, which created 900 new jobs, including 50 apprentices. Hyperdrive Innovation CEO Allan Cairns (Photo: Unknown) 
The hybrid trains are able to run on the Great Western route under either diesel or electric power, meaning that passengers can benefit from the new trains from the autumn while electrification of the line continues. 
Karen Boswell, managing director at Hitachi Rail Europe, was on the train with a number of members of staff from Newton Aycliffe. 
She said: “We trust that Her Majesty enjoyed the space, comfort and smooth ride on our new Intercity train. From the autumn, passengers will begin to feel the benefits of the new British-built fleet as they travel around the Great Western route.” Hyperdrive in Cramlington (Photo: Handout) 
The Great Western trains are one of a number of orders won by the Hitachi plant since it opened two years ago. It is also building trains for East Coast and Hull Trains, and calls have been made for the plant to get the order for HS2 rolling stock. 
Hitachi’s global chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi has warned, however, that the long-term future of the plant would rely in part on the Government negotiating a Brexit deal that allowed the company to export trains to Europe. 
Renowned Victorian engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel created the GWR route the royal couple travelled along and they were joined for the journey by his descendant, Isambard Thomas. 
Mr Thomas, 53, Brunel’s great-great-great-grandson, said after the journey: “I think train travel is a quicker way to get around because the roads are too congested now.” Like us on Facebook
